Posts.Content: It's been a long journey for me. Prior to my diagnosis, I was exposed to lot of negative prostate cancer discussions regarding the value of the PSA test and specifically, patients being over treated. Because of this, my initial high PSA reading was more an annoyance than a fear to me. I was referred to a urologist and she suggested a biopsy. My initial PSA was 8.1 and then corrected to a 4.8 with two weeks of antibiotics. I have no symptoms and a normal size prostate. I very reluctantly agreed to a biopsy. It was January 2012 for my initial reading and the Biopsy occurred at the end of July and resulted in one core of 3+4 and several 3+3. I had a subsequent Endorectal MRI that was negative. When the urologist suggested the biopsy, I began to take this whole prostate issue more seriously and started doing a lot of reading and research. I was mostly influenced by a book by Dr Aaron Katz. He clearly explained all the issues and therapys and I was very intrigued by his "Holistic Therapy". In fact, I actually started taking his recommended supplements, changed my diet to "Organic" and began a strong exercise routine and am still following this routine today. I have never been a vitamin/supplement kind of guy and was skeptical, but I figured that the only downside is the cost of the supplements. I figured that this approach was like active surveillance with an improved lifestyle. Even if I decide on a procedure in the future, I felt that I would respond to the treatment much better if I was in optimal physical condition. After reading many sad stories of men like me whose cancers progressed made me reconsider possible treatment. I began to worry that I may have waited too long and missed my early detection opportunity to rid my body of this cancer. My reluctance to choose any treatment was because of my fear of the side effects (Quality of Life). It seems that most treatments had trade offs and probable side effects. In December, I came across two new (new to me) treatments. Proton therapy at Loma Linda and HDR Monotherapy at UCLA. I read two books on Proton therapy and was almost sold. I live in Sacramento, so I decided to visit both Loma Linda and UCLA . It is about a six hour drive from Sacramento to these locations. I can expand upon my decision at another time, but will simply say that HDR Treatment at UCLA was a clear winner and I have scheduled treatment for February 27th. Although, somewhat invasive, I felt that because this treatment offered a 95% cure rate and very minimal side effects (if any) and was administered by one of the top medical/urology Centers (UCLA) in the Country/Worldthat this was the way to go for me. With all that said, I must add a very intriguing part of my story. Getting back to the "holistic approach".......my PSA at the time of my biopsy (July 2012) was 5. My next PSA reading came DOWN to 3.8 in November 2012 and guess what?? My PSA came DOWN to a 3.0 in late January. I am still fully committed to my HDR treatment but am very intrigued by my lowered PSA reading. Did the holistic approach actually shrink my cancer...or merely mask the PSA reading? I have read that PSA does not go down without treatment. Regardless, my lowered PSA has to be very positive to my treatment plan and recovery. I would appreciate any comments and will post results as I progress through my therapy.
Posts.Title: Newbie: My Story

Posts.Content: My supplements do not include Saw Palmetto. In general, my supplements include Vitamin D3 5000 units. This was actually recommended by my GP because my Vitamin D was tested and was very low. My last test in November showed that my Vitamin D increased to normal levels. I am also taking a Multivitamin. Other supplements include Omegas, tomato and pomegranate compounds, AHCC and mushroom compounds, and Zyflamennd (herb compounds). You can view exactly what I am taking by reading Dr. Katz "Prostate Health:from Conventional to Holistic Therapies". I am reluctant to name specific supplements because I don't want to be viewed as endorsing any specific brand or supplement.
Posts.Title: Newbie: My Story

Posts.Content: I am relatively new to this forum and am not sure what "provide contacts via PM means". I'll be more than happy to share my research with you. I see that you live in California. UCSF (San Francisco) also offers HDR; however UCLA is the real pioneer of this treatment. I recommend this link http://www.cetmc.com/prostate.html and also http://www.cetmc.com/highvolume.html#hdrmono_stat that shows Monotherapy to have a 96% success rate after 8 years. They have a limited history for Mono-therapy because it is so new. Depending on your circumstances, they may combine HDR with external radiation.
Posts.Title: Newbie: My Story

Posts.Content: Thank you for your response. Actually, UCLA is reviewing my slides as part of their pre-op procedure as well as viewing my Endorectal MRI. They also required certain blood tests, EKG and lung X-ray. They also performed (I believe) an ultrasound on the spot to view my prostate which proved to be normal size and shape.

Posts.Title: Newbie: My Story

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi Tom, Getting right to he point, the supplements may very well be masking your true PSA. You don't say what you've been taking but there are a number out there that are well known to do that. The most common one is probably saw palmetto which is commonly used to reduce the symptoms pf BPH. Based on the time frame and your G scores, I highly doubt that you've waited too long however, bear in mind your cancer IS NOT being cured by a holistic approach. I think you've made a wise choice as far as treatment. Just stay healthy with a balanced diet and plenty of exercise and I'm sure you'll be around a LONG time. Best of luck! --- Dave My supplements do not include Saw Palmetto. In general, my supplements include Vitamin D3 5000 units. This was actually recommended by my GP because my Vitamin D was tested and was very low. My last test in November showed that my Vitamin D increased to normal levels. I am also taking a Multivitamin. Posts.Title: Newbie: My Story

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi, Sorry to hear you are no longer a candidate for AS, not with some Gleason grade 4 involved. Also sorry you have joined the club here. Can you tell us your age and your PSA history? One "good" thing about your Gleason 7 score is that it is 3+4 instead of 4+3. If you are not familiar with how Gleason scores work, the primary type of cancer cell is identified with the first number and the secondary type is the second number. They add the two numbers together to give the Gleason SCORE. Gleason grades range from 1 through 5 with the lower the numbers the less aggressive. Anything with grade 3 or less is considered low risk. Grades 4 & 5 are more aggressive. In turn, Gleason scores of 6 or less (the combination of the two numbers) are considered low risk. A Gleason 7 is a moderately aggressive form. Scores 8-9-10 are increasingly aggressive as the numbers go up. So your 3+4=7 score means that most of the cancer cells are the less aggressive 3. But, with those grade 4 cells in there, the reasoning for AS pretty much fades out in favor of some form of treatment. You are doing the right thing in visiting a radiation oncologist. It's best to seek a highly experienced one so you can learn all the pros & cons of the different forms of radiation treatments and how they might apply to your case. Be sure that the surgeon you are seeing is also highly experienced. A minimum of 300 previous cases is what you should look for. Others here will probably have info on proton therapy. Wishing you the best of luck! Chuck Your numbers are similar to mine. I went to Loma Linda and talked with their Doctor. I also went to UCLA and spoke with their radiologist about HDR Monotherapy and overwhelmingly chose UCLA. I am 4 weeks post procedure and have very minimal side effects remaining. I urge you to google UCLA HDR Monotherapy. My insurance covered it all and their 8 year success is 96%.
Posts.Title: What to do

Posts.Content: I have been implementing Dr Katz holistic therapy since last August. If you read his book "The Definitive Guide to Prostate Cancer: Everything You Need to Know about Conventional and Integrative Therapies", you'll have a much better understanding of why these supplements were chosen. I believe that a strong exercise program and diet (I chose organic foods) are equally important. Last Spring, my PSA was 8.0, then corrected to 4.8 with antibiotics. In July, my biopsy showed 6 cores at 3+3 and 1 core at 3+4. I thought surgery was way over treatment and did not want to be tethered to diapers for the rest of my life. I began the holistic therapy in August. My first PSA in November was 3.8 and then 3.0 in February. In the meantime, I decided on a newer Brachytherapy (HDR Monotherapy, radioactive seeds are removed)...completed in April...no side effects remaining at this point....and waiting for PSA test in July. I feel the the holistic therapy is just as important post therapy as ever. One of the important supplements recommended by Dr Katz (GCP) was used in an independent 2013 research article where GCP was tested successfully for advanced prostate cancer, please go to http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/publish/news/newsroom/7503
Posts.Signature: Age: 64 HDR Monotherapy April 4, 2013 PSA: 2/12 8.0 3/12 4.8 after antibiotics 7/12 Biopsy 5x 3+3 and 1x 3+4 Began holistic therapy (dr Katz) 11/12 3.8 2/13 3.0 4/13 HDR Monotheraphy UCLA (Bracytheraphy without seed implants) Very minimal side effects remaining
Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Tom - Thank you so much for your response. I printed out the article from UC Davis, and i will download his book tonight. This is very encouraging, to hear your story so far. I wish you the best, sounds like things are going in the right direction. BTW do you see him at Winthrop, or Columbia-P? Just curious. I did consult with him in August/September 2012 at his office near Winthrop University
Posts.Signature: Age: 64 HDR Monotherapy April 4, 2013 PSA: 2/12 8.0 3/12 4.8 after antibiotics 7/12 Biopsy 5x 3+3 and 1x 3+4 Began holistic therapy (dr Katz) 11/12 3.8 2/13 3.0 4/13 HDR Monotheraphy UCLA (Bracytheraphy without seed implants) Very minimal side effects remaining
Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: Here is an interesting article that may help. Go to http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/publish/news/newsroom/7503. I'm a great believer in organic diet, exercise, and certain supplements. I've been taking this GCP mentioned in this article for about eight months and reduced my psa from 8 to 3.0
Posts.Title: Has anyone tried the Plant Programme diet?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by malbaby What is the average length of time for being on Flomax. I am now 7 months post Bracchy and still need it for manageable urination. I am 3 weeks post Brachytherapy (HDR from UCLA). They put me on Flomax about a month prior to my therapy with the intention of switching to Cialis. I have now switched to Cialis. They indicated that I would be on Cialis for 6 months or longer. My flow seems to be pretty close to normal at this point. Erections seem normal as well.
Posts.Title: Flomax post Bracchytheraphy

Posts.Content: Wow...you really gave me a lot to think about! I'm especially impressed when you said " You can't go wrong at UCLA with Jeff Dermains, and I would always go with the most skilled doctor ". I very much appreciate your advice!
Posts.Title: Photon vs hdr

Posts.Content: I've narrowed it down to HDR at UCLA or proton at Loma Linda. I'm really leaning to proton because the procedure (although, much longer) is much less invasive with lower side effects......BUT....BUT....UCLA with 95 percent success. Tough decision....your thoughts? 3+4, no spread beyond prostate
Posts.Title: Photon vs hdr

Posts.Content: Can you expand? What are the advantages of HDR over proton?
Posts.Title: Photon vs hdr

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blueox1127 I was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer psa 6.3 cancer in 4 out of 11 cores on one side 3+3.I am leaning towards removal as best option for cure.The doctors I have been dealing with are Dr.Harry Ionatti and Dr.Gyan Pareek Ihave met with Ionatti have an appointment with Pareek have also set up a phone consult with Dr Samaddi in N.Y I was wondering if anyone has had surgery with any of these Docs or of a place to find this info.It has only been two weeks since diagnoses so i feel i have time to look around and make an informed decison on best doc for surgery,any info would be welcome,thank you I was considered a medium risk cancer patient because I had one core that was a 3+4. My biopsy was last July and my first doctor, who was a surgeon, recommended daVinci surgery and spoke negatively about radiation. I had done a lot of research prior to my biopsy and came upon so many articles that emphasized that there is so much over treatment of low to medium risk patients and that many men are left with no sex life and tethered to diapers and the closest toilet. I read awful stories all the time on this forum. Last night I read where one man can not sleep at night because he has to urinate hourly if fear of waking up in a pool of urine. Horrible sexual issues are abundant. I consider you blessed with the gleason scores you have. Because of your low cancer risk, you have many options open to you that would not compromise your "Quality of Life" and would be equally effective in ridding your body of this disease. My advice (you have plenty of time) is to talk to many doctors to get different perspectives. I met with 6 different doctors and learned so much. I just finished my chosen therapy , HDR (High Dose Radiation) Monotherapy at UCLA about two + weeks ago. I can honestly tell you that I am about 90%+ recovered (including Sexual Function) with minimal side effects that are improving daily. I've been working out at the gym, riding my bike and feel great. My therapy also shows a 96% success rate after 8 years. By success rate, I mean that subsequent PSA scores are within standardized limits.
Posts.Title: treatment in rhode island

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blueox1127 The doctors i spoke of are from Miriam hospital.I met with radiation oncologist today he like my urologist agree i should have it removed,meeting with Dr David Samadi Mt.Sinai hospital in N.Y on saturday about robotic ,seems to be the best option,just have to chose the surgeon and Dr.Samadi seems to be one of the best hopefully!! I'm curious as to why the radiologist recommended surgery. Was it because of your age and lifespan? Do you have BPH (enlarged prostate complications)?
